quiz.question: What single-word term describes a systematic deviation or consistent error introduced in measurement or sampling?
Which rank-based correlation coefficient measures the strength of a monotonic relationship between two variables?
Which test assesses the equality of variances across groups and is commonly used prior to comparing group means?
Which statistic commonly denotes strength of evidence against a null hypothesis in many hypothesis tests?
Which fundamental theorem explains why sample means approximate a normal distribution as sample size grows large?
Who introduced the boxplot in exploratory data analysis to summarize distribution shape and identify outliers visually?
Which general term denotes how widely values in a dataset are spread or dispersed around a central value?
Which mean is most appropriate for averaging rates such as speeds when equal-distance segments are considered?
Which nonparametric test compares survival distributions between groups using observed-versus-expected event counts over time?
Which plot best visualizes the relationship between two quantitative variables as plotted points?
Which Victorian-era scientist introduced early ideas about regression toward the mean and anthropometric studies?
Which estimator property ensures estimates converge in probability to the true parameter value as sample size increases?
Which basic measure describes the difference between the maximum and minimum values in a dataset?
Which parametric test compares the means of two independent groups assuming approximate normality and similar variances?
Which information criterion balances model fit against complexity by adding a penalty proportional to number of parameters?
